newsitem.title: USA: Tobacco stocks slip after Miami court ruling.
newsitem.headline: Tobacco stocks slip after Miami court ruling.

text.p: Shares in U.S. tobacco companies dipped Monday after a Florida judge refused two motions sought by the tobacco industry in a second-hand smoke lawsuit brought by airline flight attendants.
Judge Robert Kaye refused tobacco industry requests to deny the plaintiffs punitive damages and to decertify the suit as a class action.
Philip Morris Cos Inc fell 1-1/8 to 42-7/8, RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp fell 3/4 to 31-5/8, and Lorillard parent Loews Corp fell 3/8 to 96-7/8.
Chewing tobacco maker UST Inc, which was dropped as a defendant in the suit because its products have not been linked to any of the plaintiffs, fell 3/8 to 28-1/8.
The suit, known as Broin v Philip Morris et al., is one of many pending against the tobacco industry. Some tobacco analysts view the case as one where the industry has a solid chance for victory.
Kaye ruled on the tobacco industry motions Friday. His rulings were sealed until this morning.
Jury selection in the trial is to begin today.

"I think this is one case where the companies have a very good case," said John Maxwell, analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer. "If there's one case that bothers me it's the Mississippi case, because there's no jury, only a judge."

Maxwell was referring to a Medicaid reimbursement lawsuit to be tried in Mississippi. In a statement late Friday, Philip Morris said the Chancery Court of Jackson County (Miss.) had ruled the suit would not be tried before a jury.
Philip Morris expressed disappointment with the ruling and noted that trials in Florida, Texas and Minnesota would be arugued in front of juries.
